title: Félix Sarriugarte
text:
Félix Sarriugarte Montoya (born 6 November 1964) is a Spanish <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and former player.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Durango%2C%20Biscay">Durango, Biscay</a>, Sarriugarte represented <a href="Athletic%20Bilbao">Athletic Bilbao</a> for five seasons – having arrived at the club at age 16 – but only started featuring regularly for the first team in <a href="1986%E2%80%9387%20La%20Liga">1986–87</a>, after appearing in 99 games for <a href="Bilbao%20Athletic">the reserves</a> and scoring 29 goals. He then spent another five years in <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> with <a href="Asturias">Asturias</a>' <a href="Real%20Oviedo">Real Oviedo</a>, where he was also never relegated (but played only three matches in his last two seasons combined).
Sarriugarte retired in 1996 at the age of 31 after playing <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">one season</a> with <a href="UD%20Las%20Palmas">UD Las Palmas</a> and splitting <a href="1995%E2%80%9396%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">his last year</a> with local <a href="Barakaldo%20CF">Barakaldo CF</a> and <a href="UDA%20Gramenet">UDA Gramenet</a>, with all the sides competing in the lower leagues. In the top flight, he amassed totals of 159 matches and 28 goals; his debut in the latter competition came on 9 September 1984 in a 0–3 away loss against <a href="Sevilla%20FC">Sevilla FC</a>, due to a <a href="Strike%20action">strike</a> from the professional footballers.
Coaching career.
Sarriugarte took up coaching in the early 2000s, with the <a href="Athletic%20Bilbao%20cantera">various sides</a> of his first club Athletic. On 8 July 2006, following the dismissal of <a href="Javier%20Clemente">Javier Clemente</a>, he was appointed first-team manager by president <a href="Fernando%20Lamikiz">Fernando Lamikiz</a>; just four months later, however, he was relieved of his duties after a 1–3 home defeat against <a href="Sevilla%20FC">Sevilla FC</a> which saw them drop into the 18th position, and eventually again <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20La%20Liga">barely avoiding relegation</a>.
In June 2009, Sarriugarte signed at <a href="CD%20Varea">CD Varea</a> (soon to be named <a href="UD%20Logro%C3%B1%C3%A9s">UD Logroñés</a>), <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Tercera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">freshly promoted</a> to <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">Segunda División B</a>, but stepped down before <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">the campaign</a> began. On 16 July 2012, after having led <a href="Sestao%20River%20Club">Sestao River Club</a> to <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">safety in that level</a>, he joined another team in the same tier, Oviedo.
<a href="Charlotte%20Independence">Charlotte Independence</a> announced on 17 January 2019 that Sarriugarte had joined the technical staff of the club as an assistant manager, under <a href="Jim%20McGuinness">Jim McGuinness</a>.
